message: In 2016, I testified at the International Trade Commission on steel-related trade cases eight times.  As we enter 2017, I will continue to do all that I can to support American steelworkers and ensure that our trade laws are fully enforced.

I am looking forward to the 2017 Town Forums starting on January 7! I hold these Town Forums in order to hear directly from you about your issues of concern and provide an opportunity for discussion on how I can best serve and represent your interests. I also wish to provide an update and seek feedback on our collective efforts to transform the Northwest Indiana economy and describe the outlook for the progress anticipated during the coming year. Click below to find a Town Forum near you.

I am deeply saddened to learn of the passing of LaPorte County Recorder Barbara Dean.  I am thankful for her years of dedicated public service and my thoughts and prayers are with her family and loved ones during this difficult time.
Appreciate the great introduction to start off the Town Forum in Portage.
There is a good crowd here at the Town Forum in Valparaiso.
Pleased to meet Cub Scouts Pack 550 prior to the start of the Town Forum at the St. John Community Center.
Glad to have a free moment at the Merrillville Town Forum to speak with the Region News Team.
I thank members of the Airline Pilots Association for their participation at today's Town Forum in Merrillville.
Honored to be a part of this weekend's Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Memorial Breakfast with the Gary Frontiers Service Club.
NA

In response to the immediate impact of President Trump’s executive order to ban the entry of individuals from certain countries, should any individual in the First Congressional District of Indiana or any member of their family or loved ones need any assistance or information, do not hesitate to contact our office by clicking below, leaving a comment, or by phone at 219-795-1844.  Please leave your contact information as this will allow our office to be of assistance as soon as possible.
Testifying this morning in support of American steelworkers at the ITC hearing on illegal steel imports from China.

Pleased to be able to host a member of the inaugural class of the George Washington University Nuclear Security Working Group  Fellows.  I look forward to the continued good work of the Congressional Nuclear Security Working Group to expand bipartisan collaboration on nuclear security issues.

Please join me for the "How Would You Balance the Federal Budget?" event with The Concord Coalition!    The event will take place February 22 at at 6:00 p.m. at Valparaiso University.  Space is limited - Click below for additional details and to RSVP.    There are tremendous challenges and difficult decisions that must be made in order to balance the federal budget. I hope that individuals will be able to take advantage of this unique exercise to weigh the pros and cons of budget decisions and consider how they impact current residents and future generations.

As we proceed in Black History Month, I encourage everyone to explore the informative historical resources available through the National Endowment for the Humanities website. Though prepared for teachers, these resources provide any individual with educational material to learn more about the struggles, challenges, and achievements of African Americans.

I appreciate the action of Governor Holcomb to recognize the immediate concerns of the individuals and families living in the Calumet neighborhood in East Chicago. I will continue to do my utmost to collaborate with Mayor Copeland and all federal, state, and local stakeholders to quickly address the health and safety issues facing these residents.

I was honored to recently receive the U.S. Army’s Distinguished Civilian Service Award from Acting Secretary of the Army Robert Speer. I am committed to supporting our Soldiers and I deeply appreciate the selfless dedication displayed by all of our servicemembers at home and abroad every day.

Pleased to recently meet with Members of the Tajikistan Parliament and the Serbian Parliament and exchange ideas on current events and legislative initiatives. I thank them for their time and commitment to public service, and appreciate the good work of the Open World Leadership Center for coordinating these productive discussions.

Had a great conversation this month with Nicholas Fortin, a reporter with the Discovery Charter School newspaper. I appreciate your insightful questions and wish you the best with your continued studies and journalism.

Proud to cosponsor this legislation introduced by Rep. Bustos that requires American iron and steel to be used in projects funded through the Drinking Water State Revolving Fund. It is imperative that American taxpayer dollars are used to support workers in American steel and manufacturing communities. I will continue to work with my colleagues to support this legislation and strong Buy America requirements.

I am pleased that so many Northwest Indiana residents were able to come together around a table at this budget event, have a serious and civil discussion about our federal budget policies, and then vote and make a decision on how to move forward.  I thank everyone who participated for their sincere interest and appreciate the good work of The Concord Coalition to foster these productive conversations.

It was great to be able to sit down and have a productive discussion with Governor Holcomb and members of the Indiana Congressional delegation yesterday. As we are still in the early days of the 115th Congress and the middle of the Indiana General Assembly session, I look forward to continuing to work with the Governor and my Congressional colleagues to create more job opportunities for Hoosiers and support transformational investments in the economic and transportation infrastructure in Indiana.
Testifying this morning before the House Budget Committee in support of transformational investments in our communities.

Happy Casimir Pulaski Day! I appreciate the invaluable contribution that the Polish people and their heritage and culture provides to our nation and the Northwest Indiana community. I also want to take this opportunity to thank Steve Tokarski and the Polish American Congress – Indiana Division for the recent recognition and your great work to support the interests of Poland and Polish Americans.

I am gravely disappointed to learn that the Administration has not honored their own Buy America requirements. I will continue to do all that I can to fight on behalf of our domestic steel industry and steelworkers, and support strong Buy America requirements for public infrastructure projects that will create American jobs.

This Women’s History Month, I encourage you to explore the remarkable legacies and stories of American women at womenshistorymonth.gov, as well as through the National Park Service link below. We must continue to learn from all the women throughout history who have tirelessly fought for equality and contributed to the prosperity of our nation.

I am very concerned about the possible negative consequences this legislation will have on the citizens of Northwest Indiana. As I examine the bill, I will be asking: Will it negatively affect individuals participating in HIP 2.0? Will it effectively drop coverage for individuals now insured through the marketplace? Will it increase premiums for individuals because of pre-existing conditions or age? Will it allow discriminatory practices? I also want to assess the budgetary impact it will have on our nation and the State of Indiana. I believe that the goal of any health care legislation should be to improve the health of individuals and allow for fair and affordable access to health care for all. I will keep these standards in mind as Congress considers any legislation to change the Affordable Care Act.

I deeply regret that this revised executive order remains fundamentally inconsistent with our country’s value of inclusivity.  This order discriminates against immigrants based on their religion and also prevents extremely vulnerable populations of refugees from entering the United States.  I would add that a rigorous security vetting process is currently in place for immigrants and refugees, and that it typically takes 18 to 24 months to screen and vet each refugee before he or she sets foot on American soil.  We should always look for ways to improve this process for the security of our country, but any changes should apply to all entrants, not just a selected few.  The United States is a nation of immigrants and I am alarmed by the misguided and disorganized attempts of the Administration to implement its policies.  If anyone in Indiana’s First Congressional District has concerns about how this order will impact themselves or their loved ones, please do not hesitate to contact my Merrillville District Office, at 219-795-1844, for assistance.

I thank Senator Donnelly and Senator Young for supporting companion legislation in the U.S. Senate, and I also thank my Indiana House colleagues and all the Northwest Indiana community leaders and officials for their steadfast support for this initiative that will ultimately attract more visitors and create more economic opportunities in our region.

Had a great time recently touring the Edsal Manufacturing – Amazon warehouse in Gary. Appreciate their good work and commitment to recognizing the economic potential of setting up a business facility in Northwest Indiana.

It was great to meet with ArcelorMittal USA Plate Products as part of the Aircraft Carrier Industrial Base Coalition's Action Days.  Steelworkers in Northwest Indiana help make much of the 50,000 tons of American steel that is used in each aircraft carrier.
I will be speaking on the House floor in opposition to #AHCA shortly.  You can watch it live on C-SPAN.
I spoke on the House floor today in strong opposition to the American Health Care Act.  You can watch my full speech here:
You can also read my full statement on the American Health Care Act on my website.
Starting now:  Congressional Steel Caucus hearing on the state of the steel industry.

It was great to meet this week with Hammond High School JROTC students on the steps of the U.S. Capitol building.  I thank you for your great questions and wish you all the best in your continued studies and service.

As a Co-Chair of the Congressional Nuclear Security Working Group, I am pleased that we were able to recently host a panel discussion with experts on terrorism and nuclear security to discuss the dangers posed by unsecure nuclear material. We must continue to work to improve the security of nuclear and radiological material around the globe, and I appreciate the willingness and time of the panelists and attendees for being a part of this informative discussion.

The Congressional Art Competition is a great program that recognizes and celebrates the talent of young artists in Northwest Indiana. I encourage all high school students to participate in this outstanding opportunity.  For additional information please click below.
I am proud to support the Paycheck Fairness Act because women in Northwest Indiana and across our country deserve equal pay for the work they do.

This week, I was proud to speak at the 14th Biannual Nuclear Triad and Advanced Conventional Strike Symposium.  I appreciate the great work of all the dedicated people at the Crane Division of the Naval Sea System Command in Indiana to support our national security and our military servicemembers in order to keep our country safe.

Honored to attend a celebration for the recently formed State of Indiana National Guard Partnership with the Republic of Niger. This is a great mutually beneficial partnership between our two countries that promotes peace and regional stability in Africa. Included in this photo are MG Courtney Carr, Adjutant General of the Indiana Guard, Gen Joseph Lengyel, Chief of the National Guard Bureau, and Ambassador Hassana Alidou, the Republic of Niger’s Ambassador to the United States.  I am very proud of Indiana’s National Guard and the tremendous leadership they provide for our great nation.

Greatly enjoyed the opportunity to tour Allison Transmission's headquarter facilities last week. I thank you for all of your great work to keep our country and our military vehicles moving, and your support for creating jobs and improving our national defense manufacturing base.

I deeply appreciate the outstanding work of Stephen Mays, Bob Heisse, and Chuck Hughes for organizing and participating in last week’s World Civility Day. It was a great reminder that we all must do more to listen and approach the challenges in our world and our region with civility, not just on World Civility Day, but every day. #CivilityCounts

One of the primary functions of government is to ensure the health and safety of all citizens, which allows a viable economy to flourish and create new job opportunities. I appreciate the time and efforts of EPA Administrator Scott Pruitt, Governor Eric Holcomb, Mayor Anthony Copeland, Sen. Joe Donnelly, Sen. Todd Young, Indiana Sen. Lonnie Randolph, and Indiana Rep. Earl Harris, Jr., to see first-hand today the challenges facing the residents of East Chicago and discuss how we can continue to work together to address their immediate health and safety concerns and remedy the underlying environmental issues.

As steelworkers, their families, and citizens across Northwest Indiana have long known, the strength of our national security is invariably linked to the strength of our domestic steel industry, and that illegal steel imports have been decimating our steel and manufacturing capabilities. I am encouraged by today’s action by the Trump Administration and the Department of Commerce, and I hope that this investigation moves forward as expeditiously as possible for the sake of American steelworkers, the steel industry, and manufacturing.

I would like to wish my friend Terry Lynch all the best in his retirement. Terry recently retired from his position as Vice President of the Heat and Frost Insulators International, and he has devoted his life to the interests of men and women in the trades. I am forever grateful for his tireless work to create job opportunities in our economy and his dedication to improving the skills and abilities of our workforce.

I profoundly appreciate the long-standing dedication of the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, IDEM, IDNR, the Little Calumet River Basin Development Commission, and nonprofit organizations, as well as private citizens, for their efforts to restore and preserve this invaluable natural resource. The success of their efforts will provide immense benefits to enhance our natural environment, improve the foundation of our quality of place, and grow our economy by retaining and attracting more talented individuals to our region.
NA

This #WorkersMemorialDay, I want to thank USW Local 1010, all United Steelworkers members, and manufacturing and steel companies, for taking time to remember those who have been lost on the job and for rededicating themselves to prioritizing and improving workplace safety every day.

This past weekend, the U.S. Navy christened the future USS Indiana, which will be our 16th Virginia-class submarine.  I appreciate the extraordinary work of Huntington Ingalls Industries, ArcelorMittal, the United Steelworkers, and the countless others involved in manufacturing such an incredible vessel that will carry forward both our brave sailors and the proud name of our great state while protecting our nation. #IndianaChristening

I encourage all students interested in attending a U.S. military academy to attend the 2017 Military Academy Night at 6:00 p.m. on Monday, May 15, at Indiana University Northwest.  I am pleased to be able to host this informative meeting for any student interested in receiving an outstanding education and serving our nation.  For additional information and to access the online application, click here:  http://visclosky.house.gov/serving-you/military-academy-nominations

I remain opposed to Republican health care legislation that unnecessarily causes confusion and threatens access to health care for innumerable Americans. It is estimated that up to 24 million Americans could see their health coverage eliminated or rendered unaffordable. I believe it will harm employer’s ability to provide coverage for their employees and make it more difficult for citizens to secure positive employment opportunities. The purpose of government is to protect people, not hurt them. I am grievously disappointed in the professed policies, the lack of deliberate consideration, and most importantly, the very negative impact that it will have on the people of Indiana’s First Congressional District and our nation.  #VoteNoAHCA

I am pleased to announce the promotion of several staff members of the Washington, D.C., office who have ties to Northwest Indiana.   We are incredibly fortunate to have such dedicated staff that brings a wealth of perspectives and knowledge of Northwest Indiana to Washington, D.C.  http://visclosky.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/visclosky-announces-the-promotion-of-region-staff-in-washington-dc

Reminder - I encourage all students interested in attending a U.S. military academy to attend the 2017 Military Academy Night at 6:00 p.m. on Monday, May 15, at Indiana University Northwest.  For additional information and to access the online application, click below.

I deeply appreciate the dedicated work of the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers and the City of Hobart, including Mayor Brian Snedecor and the City Council, for collaborating together to support this investment in our region’s water infrastructure.  Because of their commitment to the Northwest Indiana community, the health, safety, and the quality of place for all residents has been improved.

In recognition of National Police Week, we honor our brave law enforcement officers in Northwest Indiana and from across our country, and we remember those who have given their lives in the service and protection of others. This week and every week, I will continue to do my best to support our law enforcement officers and extend my profound gratitude for their dedication and commitment to keep our communities safe. #PoliceWeek2017
Testifying this morning at the ITC in support of the American steel industry. #InfrastructureWeek

I would like to thank all of the individuals who participated in last week’s Military Academy Night for their time and willingness to be a part of an informative discussion on the invaluable opportunity of attending one of our military academies. I encourage any student who is interested in applying to click below and contact my office if you are in need of any information: http://visclosky.house.gov/serving-you/military-academy-nominations

This Memorial Day, we remember and honor all who have given their service and sacrifice in defense of our freedoms.  Let us carry the memory of their sacrifice forward as we continue to support our brave men and women in uniform and their families, both as they serve around the globe and as they return home.

I was honored to be able to participate this week at the Lake County Memorial Day service at Stoney Run County Park. It is right to remember those who have given their lives on our behalf. It's also important to remember the sacrifices of each of those individual's family and friends and their communities for the sacrifices and losses they have suffered.

I commend Mayor Freeman-Wilson and Chief Bradley for successfully identifying and securing this federal grant. I am pleased that this funding will further assist the brave members of the Gary Fire Department who put their lives on the line every day to respond to residents in times of need and keep our communities safe.

Is your passport expiring soon? The State Department is expecting an increased amount of applications to renew passports in the coming year and is encouraging passport holders to not wait to start the renewal process. Click below for more information on how to renew your passport and do not hesitate to contact my office if you need any other information or assistance.

The Northwest Indiana landscape, our beaches, trails, and quality of life, have been forever improved because of the environmental stewardship and life-long dedication of Dale Engquist. I have always valued Dale’s friendship and his life of public service. My thoughts and prayers are with his wife Jo Ann and his family and friends during this difficult time.

I would like to thank the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers,  Lake County Commissioner Mike Repay, Lake County Surveyor Bill Emerson, Jr., and all the members of their dedicated team who initiated this outstanding federal project. Because of their commitment to improving the storm sewer drainage system in Calumet Township, the ability to care for and protect homes in this community will be vastly improved, and will further enable the residents to thrive and contribute to our growing regional economy.
My thoughts and prayers are with the Capitol Police, my Congressional colleagues, their staff members, and all others impacted by this morning's horrible shooting.

As the Ranking Member of the House Defense Appropriations Subcommittee, I will continue to advocate for strong Buy America requirements to support our national defense and our dedicated steel and manufacturing workers as we draft our Fiscal Year 2018 legislation next week.

Pleased to sign the letter below to support strong Buy American policies in upcoming NAFTA renegotiation discussions. The letter states that Buy American laws ensure that hard-working Americans’ tax dollars are spent on products that are made domestically and stimulate local economies, and that it is vital that our trade agreements are negotiated to allow domestic content preferences. I will continue to do all that I can to support strong Buy American requirements.

I have cosponsored Rep. Pascrell’s Jobs and Trade Competitiveness Act and I encourage my colleagues to join us in defending American workers and American companies. This legislation would implement several policies that aim to support American workers, including establishing countervailing duties to offset the impact of currency manipulation, creating an Office of Congressional Trade Enforcer and new positions of Chief Manufacturing Negotiator and Chief Trade Prosecutor in the executive branch. I will continue to work with my colleagues to see that this legislation is considered as soon as possible.

Delivering my opening remarks today as the Ranking Member of the Defense Appropriations Subcommittee during the full Committee consideration of the Fiscal Year 2018 Defense Appropriations Act that allocates funding for our brave men and women in uniform.

Sent President Trump another letter with my Steel Caucus colleagues, this time in support of the Sec. 232 investigation of the impact of illegal steel imports on our national security. We encourage the President to take strong, bold action to halt the unfair trade actions that have deeply harmed the American steel industry, which is essential to providing for our national defense and economic security.

As we celebrate the 4th of July today, I am thankful for our nation’s veterans, our active duty servicemembers, and their families, for the sacrifices that they make every day so that we can enjoy the great freedoms of our country.

It is great to see the extraordinary progress that is occurring along the Grand Calumet River as plant life and animals return. I thank the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers and all of our federal, state, local, and community groups for making this progress happen.
We must do more to support and defend American unions.  They are an essential component of creating new employment opportunities with fair wages and working conditions in all sectors of our economy.

I hope as we move forward this month that Congress will realize the value of improving the health care system through an open and fulsome legislative debate. The sooner we can remove the uncertainty that has been created in the health care market because of the one-sided repeal and replace discussion, the sooner we can create positive, bipartisan improvements to the Affordable Care Act.

Pleased to be able to recently meet with Members of Parliament from Canada who also represent steel producing communities.  It was a productive conversation as we discussed how we can continue to work together to build upon our trading partnership and address global steel overcapacity issues and the threat of illegal trading practices.

I was pleased to speak in support of Congresswoman Barbara Lee’s amendment to set a timeline for the repeal of the Authorization for Use of Military Force that was established in September of 2001. We ask the brave men and women of our military to risk their lives for this nation every day in ongoing combat operations. Congress should meet its Constitutional responsibility and develop clear and current policy objectives for their service. I congratulate Rep. Lee on the successful approval of her amendment and I will continue to support this important provision as the legislation moves forward.

Appreciate the quick and dedicated response of officials at the EPA, the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, and all of the other federal, state, and local entities, who are working to address the dangerous threat of Asian Carp. I thank you for your commitment to collaborating with our communities and protecting our environment. We must continue to do all that we can to remain vigilant and support the invaluable government function of protecting our natural waterways from invasive species.

Last week I opposed an amendment that would have weakened essential Davis-Bacon Act wage protections. I am pleased that the House defeated this ill-conceived amendment, and I will continue to do all that I can to ensure that American workers receive fair wages for the work that they do.

We cannot allow any weakening of our Buy America requirements. Should we allow this exemption, we open the door to even more exemptions that would harm both our national economy and our national security. I will continue to do everything possible to make sure that American taxpayer dollars are used to support projects that use American iron and steel products that are manufactured from start to finish by American workers.

It is extremely disturbing to learn that an amendment to the 2018 Defense Appropriations bill, adopted on a bipartisan basis during full committee markup, was stripped from the version expected to be considered on the House floor next week. The amendment, sponsored by Congresswoman Barbara Lee, would have forced Congress to do its job and consider the legal basis for military action in which our nation is currently engaged. The amendment was adopted with outspoken bipartisan support, including from one Appropriations subcommittee chairman and two military veterans. Stripping this amendment despite its clear bipartisan support is undemocratic and underhanded, and it undermines regular order. It is time for Congress to stop hiding from this debate, and it is time for majority leadership to stop overruling the clear will of both Democratic and Republican members.

I am pleased that the FY 2018 Transportation and Housing and Urban Development Appropriations Act includes important language that would aim to protect transit projects that are already in the pipeline to receive federal funds. As the appropriations process continues, I will continue to work with my colleagues to support these projects and robust funding to grow our transportation infrastructure networks and build our local economies.
I congratulate Steel Cities Steels for their dedicated work to support the Northwest Indiana economy and for their notable recognition to promote the safety of their employees.
Below are my opening remarks from today's House consideration of the Fiscal Year 2018 Defense Appropriations Act.

I am pleased to announce that the winner of the 2017 Congressional Art Competition is Lily Jean Wall for her piece entitled "Nikki" and the runner-up is LaShawn Wise for his piece entitled "Covered by Country". I congratulate Lily and LaShawn, and I thank all of the Northwest Indiana students who utilized their time and talents to participate in the 2017 Congressional Art Competition. It is heartening to see such creative expressions from our Northwest Indiana students, and I wish all of them the best in their continued academic and artistic studies.

For the second time in three weeks, I voted against an amendment that would have weakened Davis-Bacon protections for workers.  I am glad that this amendment, offered to the Defense, Military Construction, Veterans Affairs, Legislative Branch, and Energy and Water Development National Security Appropriations Act of 2018, was defeated by a vote of 178 to 249.  I will continue to oppose any efforts to weaken Davis-Bacon protections and undermine the ability of workers to earn fair wages.

It was a privilege to honor Lee Botts and recognize her tireless work to protect the environment of Northwest Indiana and our lakeshore.  I appreciate the efforts of Geof Benson and the Dunes Learning Center to organize this event.
NA

Appreciate the willingness of Secretary Carson to visit with the East Chicago community today and hear directly about the challenging and difficult circumstances that face the residents impacted by contaminated soil. I look forward to continuing to work with Secretary Carson, as well as with our other federal, state, and local officials and community representatives, to protect the health and safety of individuals in this area and remedy the underlying contamination issues.
NA

I congratulate Governor Holcomb and the Indiana Ports Commission for successfully securing federal funds to improve the international port in Portage. This exciting news will benefit job creation in Northwest Indiana and our entire state! I was happy to support their grant application with a  letter of support last year and I will continue to do all that I can to advocate for investments in our transportation and economic infrastructure.

This is another great step forward for creating new economic opportunities and economic growth in our region. The success of this application will help the Gary/Chicago Airport continue to attract more charter, commercial, and cargo opportunities to Gary and our region.

As the Ranking Member of the House Defense Appropriations Subcommittee and a member of the Energy and Water Appropriations Subcommittee, both Subcommittees that are responsible for providing funds for the maintenance and modernization of our nuclear arsenal, I would note that actions to design, build, maintain, and modify our nuclear weapons system take not months, but decades to implement.     Additionally, if President Trump is referring to his order requesting a Nuclear Posture Review in January of 2017, it is important to note that the Department of Defense announced the start of this review in April of 2017, with the expectation that the final report will be given to the President by the end of the year.    Further, while President Trump’s budget request for Fiscal Year 2018 does include additional funds for nuclear weapons activities, the appropriations legislation to fund such activities has not yet been signed into law.    Additionally, our ability to keep our nation safe from nuclear threats does not depend solely on the modernization and renovation of our nuclear arsenal.  Funding for nuclear infrastructure and nonproliferation programs, which President Trump cut in his Fiscal Year 2018 budget request, has an essential role in preventing the spread of fissile and radiological materials and stopping nuclear weapons from being obtained by those who may wish to cause us harm.    The President’s loose and imprecise language is in stark contrast to the consummate professionalism of the men and women of our nuclear forces, who stand watch in defense of our country with the utmost gravity every minute of every day.  I will continue to work in a bipartisan fashion with my colleagues in Congress and on the House Appropriations Committee to make thoughtful and discrete funding decisions on how to best modernize and improve our nuclear weapons complex, while also working for a robust, multilateral nonproliferation effort, to keep every resident of our country safe and secure.

Volunteer fire departments in Porter County put their lives on the line every day while they respond to emergencies and keep our communities safe. I am pleased that these departments collaborated to successfully identify and obtain this critical grant that will support the initiative of Porter County and further improve the safety of the public and our brave firefighters.

As a member of the House Appropriations Committee, I have consistently supported funding for the National Endowment for the Arts (NEA). While the current administration proposed to eliminate the NEA in the Fiscal Year (FY) 2018 budget request, I am pleased my colleagues and I on the House Appropriations Committee worked to include $145 million for the NEA in FY 2018 appropriations legislation, which is $5 million less than the FY 17 funding level. I commend John Cain and the staff of South Shore Arts for successfully utilizing this outstanding program for our youth and our communities, and I will continue to do all that I can to support this federal program.

Happy 101st Birthday to the National Park Service!  I am proud that the Indiana Dunes National Lakeshore in the First Congressional District provides us with such incredible recreational opportunities and draws a constant stream of new visitors to our region. In honor of this birthday, entrance fees for all our national parks, including the Indiana Dunes National Lakeshore, are waived for today.

As we recognized #WomensEqualityDay this past weekend, we must rededicate ourselves to ensure that women are treated equally and receive equal pay for the work that they do. I am proud to be a cosponsor of the Paycheck Fairness Act, which seeks to end pay discrimination, and I will continue to work to see that Congress considers this essential legislation as soon as possible.

It is devastating to learn of the destruction that Hurricane Harvey is causing in Texas. I appreciate the heroic bravery of our first responders and citizens coming together to rescue people in harm's way.  We must continue to do all we can to support our fellow Americans during the challenging transition that lies ahead.

I thank Secretary of Transportation Elaine L. Chao and her staff for taking the time to hear from myself and Governor Eric Holcomb, Senator Todd Young, and Rep. Jackie Walorski about the importance of investing in the double-track project and the extension of the South Shore Line . I also appreciate the great presentation by Northwest Indiana Regional Development Authority President and CEO Bill Hanna and Northern Indiana Commuter Transportation District President Mike Noland.

Happy Labor Day Northwest Indiana!  I will continue to do all I can to amplify the voice of workers in Washington, D.C., and support organized labor in their quest for fair wages, a sound retirement, a safe workplace and good affordable health care.

As a co-chair of the Congressional Nuclear Security Working Group, I congratulate the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), the Government of Kazakhstan, and the Nuclear Threat Initiative (NTI) on their launch of the first IAEA-owned-and-operated nuclear fuel bank. This collaborative and innovative approach by civil society and government entities is a key development to furthering nuclear nonproliferation efforts and keeping our world more safe and secure.

It is deeply unfortunate that the administration’s action will create uncertainty and fear for those enrolled in the DACA program who are innocent of the actions that brought them to the United States and who have obeyed our laws. The status of these participants should be dealt with as part of a comprehensive plan and not in the manner announced today. I have long supported a comprehensive immigration solution that would aim to improve national security by strengthening border protections, limit wage competition by holding employers who hire undocumented workers accountable, and promote public safety by bringing those immigrants already contributing to our communities out of the shadows through an earned path to citizenship. Should anyone in Northwest Indiana require information or assistance with regard to his or her pending application, I would encourage you to contact my Merrillville office.
Now is the time to build upon the initial guiding principles of the Marquette Plan and realize the full economic potential of our Lake Michigan shoreline.

These projects will build upon our industrial base and create new jobs by enhancing our quality of place and attracting businesses to remain, start, relocate, and expand in our region.  We would not be where we are today without the steadfast support of NICTD, the RDA, Governor Holcomb, my colleagues in the General Assembly, and local communities and citizen groups. I am deeply grateful for all of their aggressive work to get us to this point in our journey, but this is only another step, albeit an important one, towards success.

I thank Antonio Gutierrez for his continued incredible display of advocacy by walking from Northwest Indiana to Washington, D.C., in support of cancer research. I will continue to support H.R. 1676, the Palliative Care and Hospice Education and Training Act, and H.R. 1017, the Removing Barriers to Colorectal Cancer Screening Act.

Pleased to speak on the House floor last week in support of transportation infrastructure programs that will provide funds for the South Shore Rail Line Double Tracking and West Lake extension projects.
Our veterans deserve all of our support every day of every month. Please click below to learn about veteran suicide prevention resources available from the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs.

Pleased to see the outstanding environmental stewardship of ArcelorMittal USA and deeply appreciate all of their great work to build and invest in the economy, environment, and people of Northwest Indiana.

Ten amendments were made in order during the consideration of recent appropriations legislation that would have prohibited the implementation of Davis-Bacon wage protections, and each amendment that was debated on the floor was defeated. I will continue to fight against these harmful efforts and send the resounding message that our incredible workforce deserves to be paid a fair wage for the work that they do.

The full emergency resources of the federal government must provide additional immediate assistance to those impacted by the recent hurricanes in Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands. This humanitarian crisis has left many people without basic necessities, including food and water. I will continue to do all I can in my capacity as a member of the House Appropriations Committee to quickly advance legislation that supports the expeditious and effective use of federal resources to further assist these communities in this serious time of need. If you or any of your relatives in this area may need any assistance please contact my Merrillville office at 219-795-1844.

Today I signed a letter to President Trump that urged him to further mobilize the Department of Defense to immediately deploy additional assets in support of Puerto Rican and U.S. Virgin Island recovery efforts. Specifically, the letter stated that the Department of Defense should send the USS Abraham Lincoln to the region, appoint a senior general officer to work with FEMA, and use personnel to support local law enforcement in addressing looting and crime. While recovery efforts are underway and communities are helping one another through this crisis, it is unacceptable that a large portion of the population has been underserved. To stay up to date on all my latest actions to assist in the hurricane recovery, I encourage you to contact me through my website below and indicate that you would like to receive “Hurricane Relief E-Newsletter Updates”.

Community health centers provide invaluable services to our region and countless individuals and families. That is why I am a cosponsor of H.R. 3770, the Community Health Investment, Modernization, and Excellence Act of 2017, and I will continue to do all that I can to ensure that the House considers this timely legislation as soon as possible.

Click below to visit my website page dedicated to Hurricane Maria disaster response resources. Additionally, should you or any of your friends or relatives need any assistance, please do not hesitate to contact my Merrillville office at 219-795-1844.

Had a great discussion recently with the residents and guests at the Brentwood community in Hobart. I thank all the Brentwood staff for creating the opportunity for a productive conversation on the many important issues facing Northwest Indiana and our nation.

It is great to see how Ivy Tech Community College Northwest Region is partnering with local employers to ensure that Northwest Indiana has a workforce with the skills and talents to grow our regional economy. I enjoyed recently hearing about all of their good work at the Valparaiso campus.
Pleased to recently sit down with Keith Kirkpatrick on Lakeshore Focus.  Stay tuned for the upcoming broadcast next week on October 13 at 7:30 p.m. via Lakeshore Public Television.

I am incredibly disappointed that Congress has allowed the authorization for the Children’s Health Insurance Program to expire, putting the health insurance of 9 million children in the United States at risk. We must not delay to work in a bipartisan fashion and get our work done.

Appreciate the opportunity to attend the opening of the new Lake Ridge Fire Protection District facility this past weekend. I thank all those who supported this public safety improvement to our community and I thank the dedicated firefighters who are on call every day to keep our residents safe.
I thank Marc Magill of the Jesse Brown VA Medical Center for bringing awareness to this critical issue and for recently holding a discussion on this at the Adam Benjamin VA Clinic in Crown Point.

Yesterday, President Trump continued his deliberate attempts to create fear and uncertainty for all Americans in need of quality and affordable health care. His reckless actions aim to allow insurance companies to deny coverage of individuals with pre-existing conditions and those in need of maternity care, pediatric services, and mental health and substance abuse treatments. I will continue to do all that I can to generate a bipartisan consensus on how we can build upon the current health care system to improve the availability of affordable and decent health care options.

According to the CDC, 1 in every 5 women and 1 in every 71 men have experienced rape in their lifetime. This is unacceptable. We must do more as a nation and as neighbors to prevent this dangerous trend from continuing and to support survivors. If you or anyone you know is seeking resources related to sexual assault, I would encourage you to visit the CDC’s Sexual Violence page below.

It is infuriating that 86 percent of Puerto Rico citizens currently do not have electricity and 29 percent do not have potable water.  Our fellow Americans deserve better. Last week I voted for additional emergency funding for FEMA to respond to the recent hurricanes and I will do all that I can to see that this assistance is delivered as expeditiously and effectively as possible.

Despite my clear and deep mistrust of Iran, I firmly support the hard-fought multilateral agreement and believe that it severely limits Iran’s nuclear ambitions, establishes a verifiable and robust inspection regime, allows for the timely reinstatement of sanctions for violations of this agreement, and in no way limits U.S. military options. Iran has held up their end of the agreement, as indicated by IAEA inspections and the U.S. intelligence community, and as long as they continue to abide by their commitments, so should we.

It is unacceptable that our fellow citizens in Puerto Rico continue to struggle to receive assistance for basic needs and that 75 percent of the residents remain without electricity. Should you or someone you know need any assistance, I would encourage you contact my Merrillville office at 219-795-1844 and share my website page dedicated to Hurricane Maria disaster response resources: https://visclosky.house.gov/hurricane-maria-disaster-response-resources

Pleased to join with new Congressional Steel Caucus Co-Chairman Rep. Mike Bost and Co-Chairman Representative Rick Crawford in leading this letter with 65 other Members of Congress to President Trump. The letter states that the Section 232 investigation on steel imports must be completed as soon as possible because each day that passes is another day that the domestic steel industry faces an onslaught of imports and the deeply harmful effects of unfair trade practices. The letter strongly urges the administration to release the report as expeditiously as possible so that action can be taken to protect the American steel industry and defend America’s national security.

I congratulate the Port of Indiana-Burns Harbor for their diligence to successfully obtain this federal grant opportunity. This port is an essential component of a strong and growing Northwest Indiana economy and these federal funds will help improve their ability to create jobs and generate additional economic activity throughout our region and our state.

Today, the U.S. House of Representatives approved my legislation to designate the Indiana Dunes National Lakeshore as a National Park.  Below are my remarks made during the consideration of this measure.

We are currently in HealthCare.gov's open enrollment period for coverage in 2018. Click the site below for information and do not hesitate to contact my Merrillville office at 219-795-1844 if you need any further information or assistance.

Pleased that my office was able to provide Mr. Ron Cortez, a Vietnam Veteran and Hamburger Hill survivor, a flag flown over the U.S. Capitol during the Quilts of Valor Foundation  presentation ceremony at his residence today in Schererville.
Pleased to speak with WBEZ last week about the exciting work happening in Northwest Indiana to create jobs and transform our regional economy.
Pleased to be able to recently talk with Secretary Perry and other members of the Nuclear Security Working Group about the Department of Energy’s important nuclear nonproliferation programs.

We must do all that we can to defend American steelworkers and stop the illegal trading practices of China. Their illegal subsidies, state-owned enterprises, and massive amounts of steel overcapacity remain a constant threat to American steel companies and steelworkers who are the foundation of our national economy and essential to providing for our national security.

Happy to celebrate the 242nd Birthday of the U.S. Marine Corps this week with these outstanding Marines, including Staff Sergeant Angel Rodriguez from Northwest Indiana. Thank you to all of our military personnel for your bravery and service. #HappyBirthdayMarines
Honored to be a part of the American Legion Post 260 Veterans Day program in Portage today.  Thank you to all of our veterans for your service and sacrifice.

Honored to speak at the 2017 Career Service Awards Ceremony at the U.S. International Trade Commission last week.  I congratulate all of the employees and award winners for their invaluable public service and exemplary commitment to the economic strength of our country.

Pleased to work with Rep. Adam Smith to request this CBO report, which provides a sobering account of the investment needed to modernize our nuclear arsenal. We must continue to work in a bipartisan fashion to determine the best path moving forward to ensure the safety and security of our country.

This morning I testified at the U.S. International Trade Commission hearing on carbon and certain alloy steel wire rod. I stated that we must not waiver in our efforts, and we must continue to apply pressure on countries that blatantly violate our trade laws and threaten the American steel industry and American steelworkers.

I believe that tax reform legislation must provide greater equity among taxpayers, encourage productive economic investments, and not increase the national deficit. I opposed the House Republican tax legislation because it meets none of these requirements. For example, this legislation would eliminate the medical expense tax deduction which helps seniors, the chronically ill, and individuals in long-term care facilities pay certain qualified medical expenses, repeal the tax deduction available to teachers for up to $250 of the cost of purchasing classroom supplies, and impair our local nonprofit hospitals’ ability to finance capital improvements. Instead, it is a $1.7 trillion addition to our national deficit. This legislation will require today’s children and grandchildren to finance this debt.

I support the DREAM Act because DACA participants were minors when they came to our country and are innocent of the actions that brought them to the United States. DACA participants voluntarily came out of the shadows, registered with this program, and provided finger prints and background checks to prove they have obeyed our laws. Now they work legally, pay taxes, and contribute to the United States' economy. DACA participants do not deserve to be in this situation of uncertainty and fear. It is past time that Congress allows this important bill to be debated and voted upon.

Councilman Whitlow provided an invaluable contribution to our Northwest Indiana community as an educator and member of the Michigan City City Council.  My thoughts and prayers are with his friends and family during this difficult time.
Wishing everyone in Northwest Indiana today a safe and happy Thanksgiving!

Pleased to speak with Chris Nolte on Lakeshore Public Radio’s Regionally Speaking earlier this month to discuss the actions I am taking to create jobs and grow the Northwest Indiana economy. Jump to 25:00 to listen to the discussion.

Today the House approved legislation that requires every Representative and employee of the House of Representatives to complete an anti-discrimination and anti-harassment workplace training program every year. During my tenure in office neither I nor any of my Congressional staff members have been the subject of a formal complaint. We must take this opportunity in our country to improve our workplaces and ensure that every individual is able to work in safe, civil, and respectful environment and that appropriate, formal, and transparent procedures are available to address any complaint.

The deadline to participate in HealthCare.gov's open enrollment period for coverage in 2018 is fast approaching. Click the site below for information and do not hesitate to contact my Merrillville office at 219-795-1844 if you need any further information or assistance.

Appreciate the incredible value that ArcelorMittal brings to our regional economy through their steel production and research, and also how they are a great steward of our native environment. Congratulations on receiving the “Bringing Nature Home Award” from the Shirley Heinze Land Trust.

Great to see this progress for constructing a U.S. Customs and Border Protection facility at the Gary/Chicago International Airport. I thank Gary Mayor Karen Freeman-Wilson and all the Airport leadership for their consistent work to create jobs and improve this facility. This specific investment will continue to put our region on the map by allowing direct flights from foreign countries and further create economic activity in Gary and throughout Northwest Indiana.

Pleased to recently write a letter celebrating the upcoming commissioning of the USS Indiana. A substantial amount of specialized components and materials for this incredible warship are manufactured right here in Indiana, and once it joins the fleet, the USS Indiana will be one of the most capable undersea platforms in the world. I thank all of the crew members, suppliers, and shipyard workers who are continuing to prepare this vessel to keep our sailors safe and implement its missions. I look forward to the final dedication and honoring of our great state’s namesake.

Happy Birthday Indiana! On this date in 1816, Indiana was admitted as the 19th state in our union. For additional information and historical photographs of Indiana through the years, I would encourage you to explore the resources available below through the Library of Congress.

The deadline to sign up for health care coverage in 2018 through healthcare.gov is this Friday, December 15. I am pleased that Community Healthcare System has joined the health insurance network to provide coverage under the Affordable Care Act next year as well. If you or someone you know is in need of health care coverage for 2018, I would encourage you to visit healthcare.gov as soon as possible to learn about your options.

Congratulations to the Northwest Indiana Islamic Center Inc on your 25th Anniversary! I was honored to join you in celebrating your years of positive contributions to our region and I will continue to do my best to represent you and our shared interests in Washington, D.C.

I support net neutrality and joined 117 of my colleagues this week in urging the FCC to delay today’s vote. I regret that today’s action happened on a partisan basis and that it will eliminate protections that help ensure that the Internet remains a level playing field for all users, entrepreneurs, and innovators.  I will continue to work towards a reasonable solution that secures an open Internet for all.

Signed this letter to Speaker Ryan that stated that unpaid-for tax cuts will violate the 2010 Statutory PAYGO law and trigger automatic cuts to Medicare, and that the elimination of the individual mandate will increase health care premiums. The letter further stated that we will not be complicit in any effort to undermine access to affordable health care coverage or increase costs for millions of Americans and that we will continue to oppose this reckless tax proposal.

I opposed the Republican tax bill today because it is nothing more than a $1.5 trillion tax cut paid for by working class individuals and families.  This is a bad bill for our health care system because the elimination of the incentive for individuals to obtain health insurance will create further chaos in the insurance market, increase premiums, the number of uninsured citizens, and harm the effectiveness of hospitals and doctors.    True tax reform should provide greater equity among all taxpayers, encourage productive economic investments, and not increase our national deficit.  The Republican tax bill meets none of those requirements and instead creates additional financial burdens, uncertainty, and instability in the lives of working Americans.
Merry Christmas Northwest Indiana!  Wishing everyone a safe and happy holiday today!

Enjoyed visiting earlier this month with the future leaders of tomorrow from Daisy Troop #35111 from Valparaiso. We had a great discussion and I thank our National Park Service Ranger for also taking the time to present information about our landscape and the many educational programs available at the Indiana Dunes National Lakeshore.
